algo_empirical_intro: Important: This calculator provides theoretical positions, but flute making requires an empirical approach:
algo_empirical_1: Start small: Begin by drilling holes smaller than calculated
algo_empirical_2: Test and adjust: Gradually enlarge each hole while testing the pitch
algo_empirical_3: Work systematically: Start from the lowest pitch (furthest hole) and move toward the highest (closest to blowing edge)
algo_empirical_4: Fine-tune: Small adjustments in hole size significantly affect pitch
algo_acoustical_intro: This advanced method combines Inverse Acoustic Modeling, Node Shift Compensation, and Modified Benade principles to design flutes with precision. Working backward from measured frequencies, it calculates exact hole positions while accounting for acoustic corrections.
algo_acoustical_how_1: Inverse Acoustic Modeling: Calculate acoustic length from measured frequencies instead of the reverse
algo_acoustical_how_2: Node Shift Compensation: Account for the displacement of the quarter-wave node
algo_acoustical_how_3: Modified Benade Method: Adapted for quarter-wave (closed tube) flutes like Native American flutes
algo_acoustical_how_4: Tone Hole Correction: Empirical adjustments based on hole diameter and wall thickness
algo_acoustical_calc_2: Effective length from frequency: L_eff = v / (4 √ó f) for quarter-wave flutes
algo_acoustical_calc_3: Node shift: Œî = L_eff - L_phys (displacement due to True Sound Hole)
algo_acoustical_calc_4: Corrected position: x = L_eff - Œî - C where C is hole diameter correction
step_0_desc: Choose the type of flute you want to design. Different flute types use different acoustic formulas (half-wave vs quarter-wave).
step_1_desc: Calculate the speed of sound based on ambient temperature. Temperature affects sound velocity and must be accounted for in precision calculations.
step_2_desc: Measure the fundamental frequency with weak and strong breath pressure. This helps determine the acoustic behavior of your flute.
step_3_desc: Calculate the displacement of the acoustic node from the physical length. This is crucial for quarter-wave instruments.
step_4_desc: Configure the musical notes you want for your flute and set the reference frequency (A4).
step_5_desc: Calculate theoretical hole positions based on target frequencies before applying corrections.
step_6_desc: Apply corrections based on hole diameter and wall thickness. Larger holes and thicker walls affect acoustic length.
step_7_desc: Verify that hole spacing is comfortable for human hands. Identifies holes that are too close together.
step_8_desc: Generate a complete drilling plan with tolerances. Start with smaller holes and gradually enlarge to tune.
notes_hint: Enter notes separated by commas (e.g., C4, D4, E4, F#4, G4, A4)
algo_benade_intro: Developed by physicist Arthur Benade, this advanced method provides highly accurate hole positions by considering the acoustic impedance and coupling between holes.
algo_benade_how_1: Accounts for hole diameter relative to bore diameter
algo_benade_how_2: Considers the acoustic mass and compliance of the air column
algo_benade_how_3: Uses the chimney height (wall thickness) in calculations
algo_benade_how_4: Most accurate method for professional instrument making
algo_benade_calc_2: Hole impedance: Z = f(d, D, t) where d=hole diameter, D=bore diameter, t=wall thickness
algo_benade_calc_3: Position correction: Adjusted based on hole coupling effects
